Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, nodding along as my younger sister excitedly listed all the things she wanted to do over the weekend—hiking, a movie, maybe even a family barbecue. My parents chimed in, their faces bright with anticipation, and I felt the familiar warmth of belonging. They expected me to be there, to join in, to make memories together. But in the back of my mind, I couldn’t stop thinking about the notice posted at the construction site earlier that day. There’s an optional training session next Saturday, and the foreman hinted that those who attend might be considered for more responsibility. I know how important it is to show commitment, to be seen as a team player, especially if I want to move up. The two worlds tug at me—my family’s hope for togetherness and my own drive to prove myself at work. As the conversation at the table swirled around me, I felt the pressure mounting, unsure how I could possibly meet both sets of expectations.
